content:
It is indeed true that most words ending in 〜い are adjectives in Japanese. However, I found an example of a kanji with the 囗 (kunigamae) radical and a noun formed with an okurigana 〜い:

The kanji is 囲 (い) with the kun'yomi (Japanese reading) of い. The noun formed with this kanji is 囲い (かこい), which means "enclosure" or "fence." In this case, the 〜い functions as part of a noun rather than forming an adjective.
